description.narrative: To secure long-term financial sustainability of the Armenian PA system

comment.narrative: 100,000 ha cat. I-II by 2013 300,000 ha cat. I-IV by 2016 [original targets] at least 200,000 ha cat. I-V by 2016, which represents over 80% of the all PA category I-V hectares excluding Lake Sevan [the revised target as advised by the MTR and approved by the PEB]

177,746 ha cat. I-V
During the reporting year, CNF signed an agreement for co-financial support with Gnishik Community Protected Landscape (6,010 ha). As such, 67% of all land under formal Cat. I-V Protection has improved financial sustainability.

description.narrative: Improved funding ratio of optimal needs of PAs measured by financial sustainability score card

comment.narrative: 29% (excluding non-recurring donor funding)

54% [original target]
40%
(as revised by PEB based on MTR recommendation]

$ 517,000 was disbursed by CNF in 2014, less than the planned target of $ 607,190, due to limited absorption and decision making capacities of the relevant PA management authorities. During 2015, CNF plans to disburse $ 516,620. As of June 30, 2015, CNF factually disbursed $ 359,076, on track to meet the 2015 target. Government funding to CNF-supported PAs in 2014 in AMD increased by 10% compared to 2013. A quantitative assessment of the funding ratio by means of the Financial Scorecard will be completed for the TE in 2017.

description.narrative: Critical ecosystems of protected areas providing habitats for endemic and endangered species are conserved

comment.narrative: Ecosystems are deteriorating

Habitats in 4-5 Category 1-2 PAs are conserved by 2013 [original target]
Habitats in 6-7 Cat I-V PAs are conserved by 2016 [revised by PEB as recommended by MTR.]

CNF continues established practice of providing co-financial support to 6 Cat I-V PAs: salary top-ups, equipment and running costs, with additional TA support for accounting, budgeting, planning and procurement. A pilot biodiversity monitoring program was initiated in “Khosrov Forest” PA, targeting Bezoar goat, Bear, Leopard, Lynx, Wolf, and Cinereous vulture species. CNF in cooperation with WWF Armenia initiated the implementation of a Red deer reintroduction project in Dilijan NP.

description.narrative: Ensuring sufficiency and predictability of revenue sources for the PA system
Reduce annual funding gap by $440,000 by 2013

comment.narrative: 49% of basic funding 29% of optimal funding
78% of basic funding 47% of optimal funding
In 2014, CNF reduced the funding gap by $ 517,000; for 2015 the projection is $ 516,620. As of June 30, 2015, actual expenditure in 2015 was $ 359,076, on track to reach the 2015 target.

description.narrative: US$ value of capitalization of sinking fund.

comment.narrative: Technically speaking, the value of the GEF Sinking Fund (SFAF1) is still $1,000,000, since no additional donations to this particular sinking fund were made. Meanwhile CNF has received significant donations outside the sinking fund. To give a sense of the reality of the project, CNF reports $4,267,764 (taking into account GEF funding plus 1/3 of Euro 12 million funding from BMZ plus private donations). We are therefore significantly above the target of $2,435,000. To December 2014 we spent overall $2 million in the PAs and plan a further $560,000 in 2015, reaching our total spending target of $2,435,000. In addition to this funding we have received a further EUR 5 million into the endowment, putting us on target for a long term funding capacity of $650,000 pa.

description.narrative: Number of PAs financed from CPAF

comment.narrative: CPAF is currently not financing any PAs
Four to five PAs financed by 2013

CNF continued providing co-financial support to 6 Cat I-V PAs: Khosrov Forest, Zangezur (legal successor of both Arevik and Shikahogh PAs), Arzakan-Meghradzor, Dilijan, Lake Arpi, and Gnishik Community Managed PA.
No NRM guidance exists today. 0 0

Context adapted Guidance on NRM developed, on-line training made available 2
Modest

description.narrative: Long-term annual funding capacity of CPAF available for Armenia based on its endowment, sinking fund and other regular annual commitments.

comment.narrative:
$950,000 (original target)
$650,000
(revised by the PEB following recommendation of the MTR).

In 2014, CNF’s support valued $ 517,000, for 2015 the projection is $ 516,620, on target to reach the agreed end-of-project annual target. As of June 30, 2015, actual expenditure in 2015 was $ 359,076, on track to reach the 2015 target.

description.narrative: Raising cost-effectiveness and capacities of PAs

Increase in cost-effectiveness of at least 10 PAs measured by financial score card (part II, component II); An accounting system for PAs is in place and is adopted by all PAs (Indicator reformulated by PEB after MTR)

comment.narrative: 0.08 No accounting system is in place at CNF-supported PAs (baseline revised by PEB after the MTR).

0.33 (original target)
An accounting system is in place at CNF-supported PAs (target revised by PEB after the MTR).
An accountancy software program has been installed at CNF-supported PAs, hands-on support is provided for its operationality.

description.narrative: [original target description]: Adoption of site-specific business plans at 10 PAs providing transparency on the optimum level of management costs [revised target description]: Technical assistance is in place for the preparation and the implementation of Operational Plans (OPs) by all the PAs covered by CNF (revised target description)

comment.narrative: 10 business plans adopted (original target) Technical assistance is in place for the preparation and the implementation of Operational Plans (OPs) by all the 4 to 5 PAs covered by CNF (target revised by the PEB after the MTR).
During the reporting period, guided by CNF’s PA Management Support Group, 5 PA Budget & Operational Plans were developed or updated, for Lake Arpi, Dilijan, Khosrov, Zangezur, and Gnishik.

description.narrative: Number of site managers trained in cost-effective management

comment.narrative:
At least three in a minimum of 10 targeted PAs [original target]
An accounting system for PAs is in place and is adopted by all PAs [target revised by the PEB after the MTR]

CNF engaged a full-time budgeting & procurement consultant to provide on-the-job, hands-on and help-desk support to PAs on financial and budgeting issues, particularly on accounting, procurement and reporting procedures, based on the accountancy software and training provided to the PAs by TJS.

description.narrative: Existence of electronic system to track changes in management effectiveness based on the METT score and - where appropriate - on the Financial Sustainability Scorecard.

To save energy and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by increasing the energy efficiency (EE) of municipal lighting in the cities of Armenia via the implementation of municipal investment programs and national policies.

description.narrative: To remove barriers to energy-efficient lighting in Armenia, by means of technical assessment, facilitation of financing, and development and implementation of municipal programs and national policy
Quantity of energy saved and GHG emissions avoided.

comment.narrative: Street lighting: 40 GWh of electricity consumed for street lighting in 2011, accounting for about 16,000 tons of CO2 emissions. Average fixture power consumption is 210W in 2011. Residential lighting: 550 GWh consumed for residential lighting in 2011, accounting for about 220,000 tons of CO2 emissions.

Direct energy savings of 1.2 GWh per year from demonstration projects (474 tonnes of CO2 emissions) Indirect energy savings of 20 GWh per year from replication of demonstration projects via municipal programs (8000 tonnes of CO2 emissions) Indirect energy savings of 125 GWh per year from implementation of national lighting policy (50,000 tonnes of CO2 emissions)

Direct energy savings achieved within the reporting period from demonstration projects is 127.6 MWh (9.1%) and 56.6 tonnes of CO2 emissions. Indirect energy saving from replication of demonstration projects is expected to be achieved within the next reporting period. Indirect energy saving from implementation of national lighting policy is expected to be achieved by the end of the project.

description.narrative: Municipal energy audits and technical capacity-building
Methodology for energy/lighting audit Number of municipal energy audits conducted Number of specialists and agency representatives trained Public media exposure

comment.narrative: Lack of methodology for assessing the feasibility (financial and technical) of an energy efficient lighting technology upgrade Comprehensive energy audits are not part of normal practice for public lighting in Armenia No specialized training on EE lighting is offered in Armenia Limited broadcasting of information on EE lighting

By the project midterm the methodology will be established and shared with municipalities At least 10 comprehensive audits of public lighting completed in Yerevan and other cities Training on EE lighting delivered to specialists and agency representatives in Yerevan and at least 10 other cities Media releases on outcomes of each pilot. Awareness raising materials available for general public

The methodology was developed and tested during energy audit in Yerevan city (demo site), Alaverdi, Stepanavan, Spitak and Goris towns. Total: 5 audits. 30 specialists were trained of Yerevan Municipal Illumination Company and respective municipalities on proper installation and operation and maintenance of light-emitting diodes (LED) luminaires. Seminar on technical regulation of lighting devices’ application and establishment of national testing laboratory was held by a specialists of a partner to the project, "Center of LED and optoelectronic technologies of National Academy of Sciences of Belarus" (50 participants). Awareness raising materials prepared and disseminated, including sharing during relevant events.

description.narrative: Demonstration projects Pilot projects yield cost-effective energy savings, raising the confidence and capacity of investors and decision-makers about EE lighting
Efficiency and energy savings of installed EE lighting Share of LED in demo-projects

comment.narrative: The majority of fixtures in municipal outdoor lighting sector incorporate inefficient 250W HPS lamps or 400W mercury-vapor lamps. The indoor lighting sector is dominated by inefficient incandescent lamps and fluorescent tubes.

At least five demonstration projects on a number of efficient lighting technologies completed for indoor, outdoor and street lighting. Direct energy savings of up to 0.95 GWh per year by completion of all pilots (subject to final selection of pilot size and technologies); 100% LED for outdoor (park) and indoor lighting pilots; 40% LED included in street lighting pilots.

3 demonstration projects are completed.
In Yerevan, 482 street LED luminaires were procured and installed on the road connecting the city's center with Zvartnots international airport (9 km), replacing high pressure sodium lamps with 63% energy efficiency improvement. In Yerevan Zoological Garden, 115 park LED luminaires were procured and installed as a part of full reconstruction of the lighting system. In Alaverdi, 70 street LED were installed with 55 procured by the project and 15 - by the partner NGO, French-Armenian interprofessional network. 100% LED replacement is achieved in all the three implemented demonstration projects.

description.narrative: Replication via municipal programs and associated financial instruments. Municipal lighting programs lead to widespread deployment of EE lighting and associated energy savings.
Municipal programs for EE public lighting. Financial commitments for energy-efficient municipal lighting.

comment.narrative: Municipal programs for EE public lighting are desired but not comprehensively designed, financed, or implemented.

Municipality of Yerevan develops and adopts program for upgrades of municipal lighting. Similar programs are adopted in other cities of Armenia. Savings of 20 GWh per year from municipal lighting programs. US $10 million for energy-efficient municipal lighting secured. Establish¬ment of financing mechanisms for Yerevan and other municipalities (e.g. revolving fund) from savings achieved from piloted EE measures. Support in preparation of funding proposals (including tenders for ESCOs) for cities of Armenia.

Municipal programs for Alaverdi, Spitak, Goris and Stepanavan towns are drafted. Alaverdi and Spitak drafts are shared with the owner municipalities for comments and further approval. Revolving fund concept, operation procedure and financial flow estimation methodology are developed, discussed, approved and at work in Yerevan. In Alaverdi, the revolving fund concept is under consideration.

description.narrative: National policies, codes, and standards on lighting New national policies mandate significantly greater energy efficiency and ensure product quality for lighting, particularly in residential buildings
Existence of regulations that mandate improved energy efficiency of lighting products and installations, including codes, standards, and pro-curement rules

comment.narrative: Conventional incandescent lighting is available without restrictions and consti-tutes 85 percent of residential lighting in Armenia There is no regulation on energy performance of lighting products in Armenia

Proposed improvement to existing legislation addressing minimum energy performance requirements for lighting appliances A national phase-out plan of conven¬tional incandescent lighting is adopted Other adopted policies and supporting standards New criteria (including performance and life cycle costs) for incorporation in state procurement procedures for lighting applications are developed

The energy labeling procedure, economy sector identification by its energy-intensity concept for further use in statistics and a number of other amendments after discussion were included in the amendments to the RA Law "On Renewable Energy and Energy Saving", currently pending adoption by the National Assembly of the RA. The decision of RA Government, as developed by the project, “On implementation of energy saving and energy efficiency improvement measures in objects being constructed (reconstructed, renovated) under the state funding” was approved by the Government of the RA (decision #1504-N of December 25, 2014). International experience on phase-out of inefficient incandescent lamps was studied and a respective analytical note was elaborated, including an address to legal and regulatory issues.

comment.narrative: 1. Representation and meaningful participation of women in decision making is low (2015) 2. During 2016, local elections will be held in 118 communities of Syunik and Vayots Dzor Marzes. Only 2% of the village community leaders are females (2015) 3. In average, women representation in local self-government is 9.3% (2015) 4. The Territorial Administration Reform implies major community enlargement, which is sensitive and challenging process, including for women (2015) 5. The community residents awareness and understanding of the reform is low (2015) 6. The gender dimension of the Reform need enhancement (2015)

Focus group meetings and public discussions on the participation of people with disabilities were organized in Abovyan.

description.narrative: 1. Availability of the new model of disability determination based on the conceptual framework of UNCRPD and ICF developed together with the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs by mid 2016 2. Number of advocacy and outreach events about the new model of disability determination conducted to inform relevant stakeholders and beneficiaries about the new model

comment.narrative: 1. The current system of disability determination is outdated and based exceptionally on classification becoming a barrier to effective allocation of the existing resources and realization of the rights of persons with disabilities. Development of a new model of disability determination is planned. (2014) 2. 0 (2014)
1. The new model is piloted in selected regions of Armenia with a sample of about 1,000 persons and improved for application 2. 3

1. The new model was piloted in three regions of Armenia - Yervan, Tavush and Shirak for 1033 persons. Pilot results were analyzed and assessment tools polished. The model will be applied starting March 2017 acc to Government programme. 2. 3

activity-description.narrative: Kolba Lab builds a culture of experimentation and innovation across the government, development organisations and the public. Its main activities are concentrated in Yerevan, nevertheless the products (social start-ups) and incubation services offered by Kolba can be used across the country.

description.narrative: De-risking and Scaling-up Investment in Energy Efficient Retrofits

The Preparatory Assistance Project is to organize and carry out the inception phase of the UNDP-Green Climate Fund "De-Risking and Scaling-up Investment in Energy Efficient Building Retrofits" project.
